SetextHTML æ ‡è®°: <h1>, <h2> â€œUnderlinedâ€ using equal signs (=) as <h1> and dashes (-) as <h2> in any number. ä»£ç : This is an H1 ============= This is an H2 ------------- é¢„è§ˆ: This is an H1This is an H2 atxHTML æ ‡è®°: <h1>, <h2>, <h3>, <h4>, <h5>, <h6> Uses 1-6 hash characters (#) at the start of the line, corresponding to <h1> - <h6>. ä»£ç : # This is an H1 ## This is an H2 ###### This is an H6 é¢„è§ˆ: This is an H1This is an H2This is an H6 Optionally, you may â€œcloseâ€ atx-style æ ‡é¢˜. The closing hashes donâ€™t need to match the number of hashes used to open the header. ä»£ç : # This is an H1 # ## This is an H2 ## ### This is an H3 ###### é¢„è§ˆ: This is an H1This is an H2This is an H3 BlockquotesHTML æ ‡è®°: <blockquote> Markdown uses email-style > characters for blockquoting. It looks best if you hard wrap the text and put a > before every line. ä»£ç : > This is a blockquote with two paragraphs. Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, > consectetuer adipiscing elit. Aliquam hendrerit mi posuere lectus. > Vestibulum enim wisi, viverra nec, fringilla in, laoreet vitae, risus. > > Donec sit amet nisl. Aliquam semper ipsum sit amet velit. Suspendisse > id sem consectetuer libero luctus adipiscing. é¢„è§ˆ: This is a blockquote with two paragraphs. Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet,consectetuer adipiscing elit. Aliquam hendrerit mi posuere lectus.Vestibulum enim wisi, viverra nec, fringilla in, laoreet vitae, risus. Donec sit amet nisl. Aliquam semper ipsum sit amet velit. Suspendisseid sem consectetuer libero luctus adipiscing. Markdown allows you to be lazy and only put the > before the first line of a hard-wrapped paragraph. ä»£ç : > This is a blockquote with two paragraphs. Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetuer adipiscing elit. Aliquam hendrerit mi posuere lectus. Vestibulum enim wisi, viverra nec, fringilla in, laoreet vitae, risus. > Donec sit amet nisl. Aliquam semper ipsum sit amet velit. Suspendisse id sem consectetuer libero luctus adipiscing. é¢„è§ˆ: This is a blockquote with two paragraphs. Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet,consectetuer adipiscing elit. Aliquam hendrerit mi posuere lectus.Vestibulum enim wisi, viverra nec, fringilla in, laoreet vitae, risus. Donec sit amet nisl. Aliquam semper ipsum sit amet velit. Suspendisseid sem consectetuer libero luctus adipiscing. Blockquotes can be nested (i.e. a blockquote-in-a-blockquote) by adding additional levels of >. ä»£ç : > This is the first level of quoting. > > > This is nested blockquote. > > Back to the first level. é¢„è§ˆ: This is the first level of quoting. This is nested blockquote. Back to the first level. Blockquotes can contain other Markdown elements, including æ ‡é¢˜, lists, and ä»£ç  blocks. ä»£ç : > ## This is a header. > > 1. This is the first list item. > 2. This is the second list item. > > Here's some example ä»£ç : > > return shell_exec("echo $input | $markdown_script"); é¢„è§ˆ: This is a header. This is the first list item. This is the second list item. Hereâ€™s some example ä»£ç : return shell_exec("echo $input | $markdown_script"); ListsMarkdown supports ordered (numbered) and unordered (bulleted) lists. UnorderedHTML æ ‡è®°: <ul> Unordered lists use asterisks (*), pluses (+), and hyphens (-). ä»£ç : * Red * Green * Blue é¢„è§ˆ: Red Green Blue is equivalent to: ä»£ç : + Red + Green + Blue and: ä»£ç : - Red - Green - Blue OrderedHTML æ ‡è®°: <ol> Ordered lists use numbers followed by periods: ä»£ç : 1. Bird 2. McHale 3. Parish é¢„è§ˆ: Bird McHale Parish Itâ€™s possible to trigger an ordered list by accident, by writing something like this: ä»£ç : 1986. What a great season. é¢„è§ˆ: What a great season. You can backslash-escape (\) the period: ä»£ç : 1986\. What a great season. é¢„è§ˆ: 1986. What a great season. IndentedBlockquoteTo put a blockquote within a list item, the blockquoteâ€™s > delimiters need to be indented: ä»£ç : * A list item with a blockquote: > This is a blockquote > inside a list item. é¢„è§ˆ: A list item with a blockquote: This is a blockquoteinside a list item. ä»£ç  BlockTo put a ä»£ç  block within a list item, the ä»£ç  block needs to be indented twice â€” 8 spaces or two tabs: ä»£ç : * A list item with a ä»£ç  block: <ä»£ç  goes here> é¢„è§ˆ: A list item with a ä»£ç  block: <ä»£ç  goes here> Nested Listä»£ç : * A * A1 * A2 * B * C é¢„è§ˆ: A A1 A2 B C ä»£ç  BlocksHTML æ ‡è®°: <pre> Indent every line of the block by at least 4 spaces or 1 tab. ä»£ç : This is a normal paragraph: This is a ä»£ç  block. é¢„è§ˆ: This is a normal paragraph: This is a ä»£ç  block. A ä»£ç  block continues until it reaches a line that is not indented (or the end of the article). Within a ä»£ç  block, ampersands (&) and angle brackets (< and >) are automatically converted into HTML entities. ä»£ç : <div class="footer"> &copy; 2004 Foo Corporation </div> é¢„è§ˆ: <div class="footer"> &copy; 2004 Foo Corporation </div> Following sections Fenced ä»£ç  Blocks and Syntax Highlighting are extensions, you can use the other way to write the ä»£ç  block. Fenced ä»£ç  BlocksJust wrap your ä»£ç  in ``` (as shown below) and you wonâ€™t need to indent it by four spaces. ä»£ç : Here's an example: 123function test() { console.log("notice the blank line before this function?");} é¢„è§ˆ: Hereâ€™s an example: 123function test() { console.log("notice the blank line before this function?");} Syntax HighlightingIn your fenced block, add an optional language identifier and weâ€™ll run it through syntax highlighting (Support Languages). ä»£ç : 123require 'redcarpet'markdown = Redcarpet.new("Hello World!")puts markdown.to_html é¢„è§ˆ: 123require 'redcarpet'markdown = Redcarpet.new("Hello World!")puts markdown.to_html Horizontal RulesHTML æ ‡è®°: <hr />Places three or more hyphens (-), asterisks (*), or underscores (_) on a line by themselves. You may use spaces between the hyphens or asterisks. ä»£ç : * * * *** ***** - - - --------------------------------------- ___ é¢„è§ˆ: TableHTML æ ‡è®°: <table> Itâ€™s an extension. Separates column by pipe (|) and header by dashes (-), and uses colon (:) for alignment. The outer pipes (|) and alignment are optional. There are 3 delimiters each cell at least for separating header. ä»£ç :12345678910111213| Left | Center | Right ||:-----|:------:|------:||aaa |bbb |ccc ||ddd |eee |fff | A | B---|---123|456A |B--|--12|45 é¢„è§ˆ: Left Center Right aaa bbb ccc ddd eee fff A B 123 456 A B 12 45 Span ElementsLinksHTML æ ‡è®°: <a> Markdown supports two style of links: inline and reference. InlineInline link format like this: [Link Text](URL "Title") Title is optional. ä»£ç : This is [an example](http://example.com/ "Title") inline link. [This link](http://example.net/) has no title attribute. é¢„è§ˆ: This is an example inline link. This link has no title attribute. If youâ€™re referring to a local resource on the same server, you can use relative paths: ä»£ç : See my [About](/about/) page for details. é¢„è§ˆ: See my About page for details. ReferenceYou could predefine link references. Format like this: [id]: URL "Title" Title is also optional. And the you refer the link, format like this: [Link Text][id] ä»£ç : [id]: http://example.com/ "Optional Title Here" This is [an example][id] reference-style link. é¢„è§ˆ: This is an example reference-style link. That is: Square brackets containing the link identifier (not case sensitive, optionally indented from the left margin using up to three spaces); followed by a colon; followed by one or more spaces (or tabs); followed by the URL for the link; The link URL may, optionally, be surrounded by angle brackets. optionally followed by a title attribute for the link, enclosed in double or single quotes, or enclosed in parentheses. The following three link definitions are equivalent: ä»£ç : [foo]: http://example.com/ "Optional Title Here" [foo]: http://example.com/ 'Optional Title Here' [foo]: http://example.com/ (Optional Title Here) [foo]: <http://example.com/> "Optional Title Here" Uses an empty set of square brackets, the link text itself is used as the name. ä»£ç : [Google]: http://google.com/ [Google][] é¢„è§ˆ: Google EmphasisHTML æ ‡è®°: <em>, <strong> Markdown treats asterisks (*) and underscores (_) as indicators of emphasis. One delimiter will be <em>; *double delimiters will be <strong>. ä»£ç : *single asterisks* _single underscores_ **double asterisks** __double underscores__ é¢„è§ˆ: single asterisks single underscores double asterisks double underscores But if you surround an * or _ with spaces, itâ€™ll be treated as a literal asterisk or underscore. You can backslash escape it: ä»£ç : \*this text is surrounded by literal asterisks\* é¢„è§ˆ: *this text is surrounded by literal asterisks* ä»£ç HTML æ ‡è®°: <ä»£ç > Wraps it with backtick quotes (`). ä»£ç : Use the `printf()` function. é¢„è§ˆ: Use the printf() function. To include a literal backtick character within a ä»£ç  span, you can use multiple backticks as the opening and closing delimiters: ä»£ç : ``There is a literal backtick (`) here.`` é¢„è§ˆ: There is a literal backtick (`) here. The backtick delimiters surrounding a ä»£ç  span may include spaces â€” one after the opening, one before the closing. This allows you to place literal backtick characters at the beginning or end of a ä»£ç  span: ä»£ç : A single backtick in a ä»£ç  span: `` ` `` A backtick-delimited string in a ä»£ç  span: `` `foo` `` é¢„è§ˆ: A single backtick in a ä»£ç  span: ` A backtick-delimited string in a ä»£ç  span: `foo` ImagesHTML æ ‡è®°: <img /> Markdown uses an image syntax that is intended to resemble the syntax for links, allowing for two styles: inline and reference. InlineInline image syntax looks like this: ![Alt text](URL "Title") Title is optional. ä»£ç : ![Alt text](/path/to/img.jpg) ![Alt text](/path/to/img.jpg "Optional title") é¢„è§ˆ: That is: An exclamation mark: !; followed by a set of square brackets, containing the alt attribute text for the image; followed by a set of parentheses, containing the URL or path to the image, and an optional title attribute enclosed in double or single quotes. ReferenceReference-style image syntax looks like this: ![Alt text][id] ä»£ç : [img id]: url/to/image "Optional title attribute" ![Alt text][img id] é¢„è§ˆ: StrikethroughHTML æ ‡è®°: <del> Itâ€™s an extension. GFM adds syntax to strikethrough text. ä»£ç :1~~Mistaken text.~~ é¢„è§ˆ: Mistaken text. MiscellaneousAutomatic LinksMarkdown supports a shortcut style for creating â€œautomaticâ€ links for URLs and email addresses: simply surround the URL or email address with angle brackets. ä»£ç : <http://example.com/> <address@example.com> é¢„è§ˆ: http://example.com/ address@example.com GFM will autolink standard URLs. ä»£ç :1https://github.com/emn178/markdown é¢„è§ˆ: https://github.com/emn178/markdown Backslash EscapesMarkdown allows you to use backslash escapes to generate literal characters which would otherwise have special meaning in Markdownâ€™s formatting syntax. ä»£ç : \*literal asterisks\* é¢„è§ˆ: *literal asterisks* Markdown provides backslash escapes for the following characters: ä»£ç : \ backslash ` backtick * asterisk _ underscore {} curly braces [] square brackets () parentheses # hash mark + plus sign - minus sign (hyphen) . dot ! exclamation mark Inline HTMLFor any markup that is not covered by Markdownâ€™s syntax, you simply use HTML itself. Thereâ€™s no need to preface it or delimit it to indicate that youâ€™re switching from Markdown to HTML; you just use the æ ‡è®°. ä»£ç : This is a regular paragraph. <table> <tr> <td>Foo</td> </tr> </table> This is another regular paragraph. é¢„è§ˆ: This is a regular paragraph. Foo This is another regular paragraph. Note that Markdown formatting syntax is not processed within block-level HTML æ ‡è®°. Unlike block-level HTML æ ‡è®°, Markdown syntax is processed within span-level æ ‡è®°. ä»£ç : <span>**Work**</span> <div> **No Work** </div> é¢„è§ˆ: Work No Work

S$ $P + S$ $\alpha*S-C+S$ä¸ºäº†æ¯”è¾ƒäº”ç§ç­–ç•¥çš„æˆæœ¬ï¼Œä½¿ç”¨BSå®šä»·å…¬å¼ã€ä¸‹é¢åˆ†åˆ«æ¯”è¾ƒä¸åŒè‚¡ä»·ã€ä¸åŒæ‰§è¡Œä»·æ ¼ã€ä¸åŒåˆ©ç‡ã€ä¸åŒæŒç»­æœŸã€ä¸åŒä¿è¯é‡‘ã€ä¸åŒè‚¡ä»·æ³¢åŠ¨åº¦å…±å…­ç§å› ç´ å¯¹ä¸Šé¢çš„å‡ ç§äº¤æ˜“ç­–ç•¥æˆæœ¬çš„å½±å“ã€‚ ä¸€ã€æœŸåˆè‚¡ä»·å¯¹å››ç§ç­–ç•¥çš„å½±å“1234567891011121314151617181920212223242526# å½“å‰è‚¡ä»·ä¸æˆæœ¬ library(ggplot2) S = seq(1,100,0.2) K = 25 r = 0.05 dt = 0.8 sigma = 0.12 d1 = (log(S/K) + (r+0.5*sigma^2)*dt)/(sigma*sqrt(dt)) d2 = d1 - sigma*sqrt(dt) C = S*pnorm(d1) - K*exp(-r*dt)*pnorm(d2) P = C - S + K*exp(-r*dt) alpha = 0.3 cost1 = alpha*S - P -S cost2 = C - S cost3 = P + S cost4 = alpha*S - C + S cost = cbind(cost1,cost2,cost3,cost4) df = data.frame(S, cost) plot(df$S, df$cost1, xlab = "Stock price", // ylab = "Initial Cost", type = "l", col= // "black",ylim = c(min(df$cost1,df$cost2, // df$cost3,df$cost4),max(df$cost1,// df$cost2,df$cost3,df$cost4))) lines(df$S, df$cost2, lty = 1, col = "red") lines(df$S, df$cost3, lty = 1, col = "green") lines(df$S, df$cost4, lty = 1, col = "orange") ä»ä¸Šå›¾å¯ä»¥çœ‹å‡ºï¼Œåœ¨è®¾å®šæ¡ä»¶ä¸‹ï¼Œéšç€è‚¡ä»·ä»1å¢åŠ åˆ°100çš„è¿‡ç¨‹ä¸­å››ç§äº¤æ˜“ç­–ç•¥çš„æˆæœ¬ç”±å¤§åˆ°å°æ’åºæ˜¯ï¼š3421->4312->3421 äºŒã€æ‰§è¡Œä»·æ ¼å¯¹å››ç§äº¤æ˜“ç­–ç•¥çš„æœŸåˆæˆæœ¬çš„å½±å“12345678910111213141516171819202122232425# æ‰§è¡Œä»·æ ¼ä¸æˆæœ¬ library(ggplot2) S = 25 K = seq(10, 50, 1) r = 0.05 dt = 0.8 sigma = 0.12 d1 = (log(S/K) + (r+0.5*sigma^2)*dt)/(sigma*sqrt(dt)) d2 = d1 -
